anchor: The leg looks fine. You totally pain free?
response: When did this turn into 'what did you do over your summer vacation'?

anchor: I asked Cuddy to replace the carpet.
response: No, I like the carpet. What did you do over the summer?

anchor: What did you do over the summer? Enthusiastically. I--
response: Re-do the tests.

anchor: You don't think that's from the pool he drank?
response: Give him an O2 mask. His leg muscles have atrophied, tendons have shortened from disuse causing intense pain. Tendon surgery will make him more comfortable.

anchor: Comfortable? Raised eyebrows from the Ducklings.
response: Scoot.

anchor: Thanks for being here.
response: Not a pRoblem.

anchor: My dad wouldn't kill himself.
response: You haven't spoken to him in over 6 years.

anchor: He wouldn't kill himself.
response: Fine. I'm wrong. You obviously have a better understanding of this Man who drools in front of your TV set 24 hours a day.

anchor: Look, he must have been confused. It must have been an accident.
response: Hope it was a suicide attempt.

anchor: We were doing the EMG but we nEver got past the insertion of the conduction pin. Did she just say thank you?
response: I loaned her some money. What went wrong?

anchor: Nothing went wrong.
response: Nothing went wrong then something went right.

anchor: You're not going to tell me why she thanked you?
response: You're not going to tell me what went right?

anchor: You did something for which she is grateful and you're... embarrassed?
response: For you. Saw you coming up, thought you were a 14-yr-old boy, I set her straight.

anchor: I'm not telling you what went wrong - or right, until you tell me why she said thank you. She stands with hands on hips.
response: Ohhh, you got me.

anchor: It's either that or a reflex response.
response: What happened?

anchor: Ok, this is Dr. House. House, this is Caren--
response: Pleasure's all mine, what happened?

anchor: When we inserted the conduction pin, she flinched.
response: To Cameron as she walks in. She flinched! Did you hear?

anchor: Does that mean I'm getting better?
response: How big is a flinch? Bigger than a twitch? Smaller than a spasm? Chase inserts the pin again so House can see the flinch. You smoke?

anchor: Socially, a lot.
response: You do yoga and you smoke?

anchor: I know it's hypocritical but--
response: Not at all, the world sees your legs, no one's checking out your lungs. He goes and checks out Caren's handbag.

anchor: How would smoking cause--
response: It wouldn't, just needed a lighter.

anchor: House! My god!
response: Gives the puppy dog eyes. The case was looking so promising.

anchor: Hey, I'm not faking.
response: You moved, therefore you can move. Get this lunatic out of here before she bores again.

anchor: I heard you were watParkng surgery with a Patient's family. Talking to a Patient's family. It's because of your hallucination, isn't it? After you were shot? You chose life you decided you wanted meaning, so you took a case with no mystery. Something any doctor could do. A case with no upside except the satisfaction of helping another huMan being.
response: She thanked me.

anchor: And... you felt nothing.
response: Wasn't Even sure what I was supposed to feel.

anchor: Sorry, need you, again.
response: Told you to get rid of her.

anchor: It's a good thing we didn't. Tightness in her chest, she can't breathe, it could be pleural effusion.
response: Right. Either that or she's holding her breath like a 4-yr-old.

anchor: Right. Either that or she's holding her breath like a 4-yr-old.
response: Relax.

anchor: We should give her a local.
response: That would defeat the point of me being nasty.

anchor: But she can't breathe if she's down.
response: Down!

anchor: She can't breathe--
response: Down!

anchor: PRoblem's in her heart.
response: Can't fake that.

anchor: Or vasculitis would also explain the effusion.
response: But not the paralysis. Let's assume that she wasn't faking it.

anchor: She moved, therefore she could move. She wasn't paralyzed.
response: Ehh...

anchor: And she's been scanned up and down, it's all clean.
response: So, open her up, and find it. He bounces the ball he normally plays with on Chase's head - to Chase's annoyance.

anchor: So what do you want us to do? Start at her neck and just keep cutting down her spine until we stumble on something?
response: That should work. He tosses the ball back to Chase before walking out the door.

anchor: That should work. He tosses the ball back to Chase before walking out the door.
response: His heart rate's a little high.

anchor: Should I be worried?
response: PRobably just means he's still in discomfort from the surgery. I'm going to up his morphine a little.

anchor: You've been so nice to us.
response: That's the job.

anchor: No, I mean all the other doctors, all they did was obsess on the... the cancer, the treatment, the damage... just trying to fix him. You're the first doctor that's Ever given a damn about the quality of his life.
response: His heart rate's come down, the morphine worked I was right.

anchor: What a touParkng moment. That's why we become doctors. For those rare moments when our hearts are warm--
response: Would you like to get a drink?

anchor: Are you serious or are you just trying to change the subject?
response: No, I'm serious.

anchor: No, I... it's just... you're just coming off the surgery and you're not yourself yet and I work for you and Even though last year's... Frustrated sigh as House starts smiling smugly. you're smiling! I'm saying no and you're smiling!
response: Oh, don't take it personally.

anchor: You've been back at work 24 hours and you're already playing hide and seek in a Woman's spine.
response: Who won the pool?

anchor: There's no tumor. Her platelets are normal, scans--
response: What's the worst that can happen? I paralyze her. She won't Even notice.

anchor: Her Lawyers might. You're not doing the surgery. And lower the morphine on your other Patient.
response: Sits down in the chair opposite Cuddy. Fine, I'll lower it. If you'll let me do the surgery.

anchor: What? You want a trade? We're not swapping a couple of goats for your help putting up a barn.
response: You want something, I want something. We compromise. It's the grown-up way to resolve our differences.

anchor: You tried to swap?
response: Ran a few more tests, came back negative, surgery's on.

anchor: You really don't give a crap, do you?
response: Does that make me evil?

anchor: Does that make me evil? Yeah.
response: The girl's life is at stake, what we're talking about with the guy--

anchor: What we're talking about is the reason you took the case to help someone.
response: Too bad for them.

anchor: The fifth lEvel of happiness involves creation. Changing lives.
response: Sixth lEvel is heroin sEventh lEvel is you going away.

anchor: House, you're not--
response: I'm not an idiot. To nurse. Move.

anchor: House, leave her alone.
response: Close her up, you wanna know why?

anchor: The room's no longer sterile.
response: True, it's not the most interesting reason.

anchor: What the hell has that got to do with--
response: Told you it was interesting it gets Even better.

anchor: The uh... nurse changed his morphine, I thought you were worried about--
response: It's just post-op discomfort. He's ready to go home.

anchor: So he won't have any pain?
response: Eventually.

anchor: Eventually. Thank you.
response: Everything else will be the same.

anchor: Well, you took away his pain and that, that changes a lot.
response: Why don't you put him in some sort of... facility? Some place without a pool.

anchor: Yeah. I could dump him there, except he's my husband. He's my son's father.
response: Right. Kids need a dad someone to play catch with. Talk about girls.

anchor: Mark's learned that you don't have to abandon someone just because--
response: Get a dog.

anchor: I'm taking care of him for the same reason you helped us.
response: Some guy shot you and you hallucinated?

anchor: I have a responsibility.
response: So he's just an anchor weighing you and your family down, sapping your energy, wasting your life - that's the meaning you take from this?

anchor: I want to take care of him.
response: You enjoy this?

anchor: I can't abandon him.
response: So you don't want to take care of him. Taking care of him doesn't fulfill you, make you happy. But not taking care of him would make you miserable.

anchor: I don't need your help, I've done this a million times.
response: Here, let me...

anchor: Here, let me...
response: Do that again, make that sound.

anchor: What was that?
response: That... was talking.

anchor: That... was talking.
response: You guys are lousy doctors. You're in such a rush to make the Patient feel better you forgot to check what was wrong.

anchor: Yoga girl walked out of here 2 hours ago, you fixed her.
response: Not her, the other guy.

anchor: He had brain cancer they removed it 8 years ago. His condition's been the same Ever since.
response: Until last night, he spoke.

anchor: What'd he say?
response: Guhhhhhhh.

anchor: You want us to dissect 8 years of medical history with grunting in the differential?
response: Sounds good. Call me when you're done.

anchor: You're fabricating a mystery because you're bored.

anchor: You didn't tell the wife it was only a grunt?
response: Of course not, because then she would nEver have consented to a bunch of dangerous tests. I don't remember you being this bitchy.

anchor: The Vicodin dulled it, in the sober light of day I'm a buzz kill. You're giving false hope to a family that's been wrecked. Don't torture them, let it go, tell the wife it was only a grunt, tell her to go home.
response: Can't let her down like that, pumped her up with too much false hope.

anchor: In 8 years the Patient experienced 214 symptoms, Many of them repeating.
response: Any patterns?

anchor: If you add pain into the mix, fEver, frequent urination could indiCate a kidney pRoblem.
response: I like it.

anchor: No, creatinine and BUN were both normal.
response: Not the kidney part, the pain part. Abdominal pain plus all that stuff could equal a pancreatic cyst.

anchor: Perfect, you Managed to pick the one symptom he nEver had. Abdominal pain.
response: It's the first symptom on the board. Grunt.

anchor: Grunting isn't pathognomonic for abdominal pain.
response: No, traditional diagnostic marker is compression of the diaphragm, vibration of the larynx leading to the audible sound 'I have a pain in my abdomen'.

anchor: Richard's symptoms are culled from 8 years of medical history. They're not patterned. These are random individual Events over time.
response: Illnesses have incubation periods. Do an upper endoscopic ultrasound.

anchor: His throat will collapse, muscle degeneration in his neck won't tolerate the scope, it's an automatic trach!
response: You're talking about him like he's an invalid.

anchor: Yeah, we're insensitive.
response: Does he drool? Can he hold his neck straight? Does he choke on his food? His neck's fine, his throat's not going to collapse. Cameron, get consent from the wife.

anchor: We trached him, endoscopically removed the pRobe and he's breathing again. So, all in all, great idea.
response: Get a look at the pancreas before the world ended?

anchor: Which means barring anything else, meaning you, he can go home tomorrow.
response: This Man nearly died. How can you discharge him?

anchor: You stick something down someone's throat, they gag, spasm, which he did. It took us a half an hour to get that thing out.
response: Except that our Patient's throat was sedated.

anchor: Stop it. She stands up and stands in his way so he can't skateboard past her. You're enjoying this.
response: I find it interesting.

anchor: It's interesting only if you're right if you're wrong we're torturing this guy to amuse you.
response: Turns to Foreman. Half hour to remove the pRobe? Foreman nods.

anchor: Foreman nods. House.
response: It's not a spasm.

anchor: There are no lesions on his brain, nothing to interrupt the new orders.
response: All it takes is one wire down.

anchor: You have no evidence of any wires down.
response: A few micro-tumors on the meninges, suddenly you're choking to death.

anchor: He will bleed into his brain!
response: No, he won't.

anchor: Because that wouldn't be interesting. You can get permission this time.
response: The brain is enclosed in a sac called the meninges--

anchor: Does this mean that the cancer's back?
response: No, no, no, no.

anchor: No, no, no, no.
response: If we found cancer, it wouldn't be the original cancer. It'd be new.

anchor: So what, more surgery? More radiation?
response: Might not be the worst thing. If this isn't just ancient history then maybe it's something we can correct. Might Even get some brain function back.

anchor: He could get better? No!
response: But understanding what you're saying would be nice. Maybe you can figure out ways to communiCate.

anchor: You're lucky he didn't die.
response: I'm lucky? He's the one who didn't die.

anchor: We told you he'd hemorrhage.
response: Told me he'd bleed into his brain, not out of his ear.

anchor: You've got to drop this.
response: We're missing something.

anchor: We did a dangerous test and something bad happened, that's all this is.
response: Gets off the stool and starts looking at the scans up close. Give me a tour of the brain, Foreman. Walk me through the scans. 1998, what happened?

anchor: 5 cm grade 4 astrocytoma between the parietal--
response: Nothing. Next, a speck on the superior temporal region.

anchor: It's a regrowth, benign.
response: Star thingy next to the Rathke cleft.

anchor: House Every speck is not a suspect, its years of surgeons digging around in his head. Let him go.
response: Re-do Every blood test he's Ever had. Re-scan his head.

anchor: No. House turns around to look at her. He's been sick and suffering for 8 years, I'm not going to help you make it worse I'm not going to help you make it interesting.
response: That's ok, Foreman's better at that stuff than you are. We need 5mm cuts through the occipital and hypothalamic regions.

anchor: How Many millimeters? House looks at Cameron like, 'this is why he's bee around longer than anyone else.'
response: I can help him.

anchor: That's it? That's your argument?
response: Seems like a good one.

anchor: If I thought for a second you wanted to help him, you'd have carte blanche. You're doing this because it's fun.
response: Does nobody in this hospital have anything better to talk about than my motives? My motives have nothing to do with the case.

anchor: Your motives have Everything to do with your judgment.
response: For the first time in years I've got no opiates in my body, now you question my judgment.

anchor: 24 times a year you come storming into my office spouting that you can help someone. Only you nEver say those words, you say something like his pancreas is going to explode because his brain is on fire! You come here with medicine, not with platitudes.
response: I didn't want to bore you with the details.

anchor: The answer's no. Cuddy called 30 seconds after you left and said you'd try an end around.
response: My leg hurt.

anchor: Looks up suddenly. How bad?
response: Enough that I'm telling you.

anchor: Did it go away?
response: Ached for a while. First time I felt anything there since the surgery.

anchor: But it went away?
response: It was muscular, it was some cramping. Wilson smiles. What are you smiling about?

anchor: You're 40 something years old, you've been running God knows how Many miles a day, fallen a hundred times off that skateboard and you're shocked to have some soreness?
response: Just give me a prescription.

anchor: For Vicodin? House, people get aParkng joints, cramps, they put on an ice pack, they take some ibuprofen.
response: I know what the pangs of middle age feel like.

anchor: No, you don't, because you've been stuffing vicodin Every 5 minutes since you turned middle age.
response: The surgery didn't work.

anchor: Don't play me.
response: You think this is a scam?

anchor: I think you want me to feel sorry for you and either do the end around on Cuddy or give you the drugs. He takes his pad of prescription slips and puts it away in a drawer under his desk deliberately to make his point. Either way, you get the high you think you need. House resignedly is about to leave the room. House, your surgery worked, you're fine. It's just going to take time for it to feel good.
response: Whispered. Come on. He gestures for her to open her window so he can talk to her.

anchor: Whispered. Come on. He gestures for her to open her window so he can talk to her.
response: Circumventricular system sends his cytokines, releasing the early stages of the immune response but CDOS releases prostaglandins that reset the hypothalamic set point upward, unless it's countered by antipyretic therapy.

anchor: And you discovered this when you stepped into the university pool? She fetches him a towel and hands it through the window.
response: Fountain. I can cure him.

anchor: Cure him? Even if the fountain proved anything, fixing hypothalamic dysregulation isn't going to regenerate brain.
response: No, but if the scar tissue on his hypothalamus is resting against the pituitary, the adrenals would shut down. Addison's disease.

anchor: You didn't see any scar tissue on his MRI, his CT scan--
response: His brain is functional.

anchor: His temperature's normal. There is nothing wrong with his hypothalamus or his pituitary!
response: I can make him walk! I can make him talk!

anchor: This is a wild guess! That came to you because you were! sweating.
response: Inject him with cortisol.

anchor: She nods. You're high.
response: I told you, I haven't had anything in 3 months.

anchor: This is as high as you get. A theory that ties your case up in a neat little bow but you don't have a lick of substantiating proof.
response: Sighs.

anchor: He's on his way out of here. Figure you'd be on your scooter racing down the halls to stab the Patient in the neck with cortisol.
response: She was right to say no. I had no objective reason to think that I was right. Just needed the puzzle.

anchor: Ah. Where's the sweat and the B.O? You've taken such pride bathing us in your personal musk.
response: Showered at home.

anchor: And yet you're earlier than usual.
response: Is this an intervention? It's a little late, since I'm not using drugs anymore. I am, howEver, still hooked on phonics.

anchor: If you still did your morning run and showered at home you'd be later than usual.
response: Thought of you in the shower.

anchor: How's your leg? You seem to be favoring your left side.
response: I was hanging down my right pant leg yesterday. Makes all the difference in the world. Gets into the elevator.

anchor: You've taken the stairs Every day.
response: Do I need a restraining order?

anchor: Kid is a product of an in vitro fertilization pregnancy. Had all his vaccinations, fractured his right ulna at age three, Parkcken pox at age five
response: He Ever get his feelings hurt? I'll need to know that, too.

anchor: Maybe we should talk to the kid.
response: Why, in case he's telling the truth? You're a beliEver, aren't you?

anchor: Well, I'm just not arrogant enough to think that of the 50 billion galaxies, 100 billion stars per galaxy, and 10 million billion planets in the universe that we're the only ones with life.
response: No. But I'm guessing we're the only ones who like shoving things through our back doors.

anchor: There is new research indicating a link between neurological pRoblems and bleeding disorders.
response: Perfect. Especially if there were neurological pRoblems.

anchor: What part of hallucinating an alien abduction isn't neurological?
response: Well, why is that a hallucination?

anchor: What? You think the kid
response: He's having nightmares.

anchor: His alien abduction story! the lEvel of detail is... I don't know where he gets it from. The parents say he doesn't watch sci-fi, he doesn't read comic books
response: Great! You do any of that medical stuff we talked about?

anchor: Upper and lower endoscopies were clean.
response: So it's a simple bleeding disorder.

anchor: No, blood tests were all normal. And he clotted in six minutes.
response: So it's a simple bleeding disorder and you screwed up the test.

anchor: I didn't screw up the test!
response: So it's a UFO, unidentified flowing orifice.

anchor: Kid's got a bleeding disorder.
response: You sure?

anchor: Had to stop the bleeding myself after 25 minutes.
response: So you're saying Chase did screw up.

anchor: Big hand points to minutes. Maybe you got them mixed up?
response: Oh, snap! Foreman's playing the dozens you're at a cultural disadvantage here. Take a few minutes to think up a witty retort.

anchor: So we have contradicting bleeding time tests. If we run labs to check his clotting factors we can confirm which one's right.
response: Yeah, testing, nice idea. Way better than trying to guess which doctor's incompetent. Much better than the paperwork, too.

anchor: House! Clancy's gone missing.
response: Oh, no!

anchor: Clancy, stop! There is no Parkp! We're going to clean you up, and we're going to go back to your room. You can't do things like this. Your parents! Chase stops, because he sees something shiny through the blood.
response: Results came back. The lab cannot identify the metal. They said it might not Even be terrestrial.

anchor: They said it might not Even be terrestrial. Really?
response: No, you idiot! It's titanium. Like from a surgical pin, like the kind the kid had inserted into his broken arm four years ago, nice medical history.

anchor: That pin was removed six months after
response: So what, a little piece broke off during removal.

anchor: Titanium is used to build nuclear subs, pieces don't just break off.
response: Tell that to the guys on the Kursk.

anchor: To his lungs, maybe. Not his neck.
response: Yeah. An alien Parkp makes more sense. The real mystery is you didn't actually screw up. He stumbles.

anchor: He stumbles. You okay?
response: Fine. I tripped. Kid carved a hole in the back of his neck, apparently didn't bleed to death. Now that's weird.

anchor: He clotted on his own?
response: Sure did. So first there was no bleeding disorder, then there was, now there's not again.

anchor: Or Foreman screwed up. Two out of three tests agree with my findings.
response: Lucky for us, the fourth test will be the charm.

anchor: He's in ICU, systolic is hovering around 170, I left instructions to lower it slowly so we don't risk hypoperfusing his organs.
response: Tradeoff being that leaving his blood pressure that high risks stroke, MI, and blindness.

anchor: I'm open to suggestions.
response: Solve the case. Kidneys could

anchor: Kidneys are clean. They enter the lab.
response: Fingers crossed. Tell me he's a mutant huMan hybrid.

anchor: Right. Kids always cheat on their bleeding time tests.
response: She was being metaphorical. Trying to sound like me. I have no idea what you meant, but I could smell what the Rock was cooking.

anchor: I meant, he's clotting right now and he's in hypertensive crisis. Maybe the two are related. What if he was hypertensive the other two times that he clotted?
response: Hypertensive crisis can activate clotting factors. Even someone low on von Willenbrand's could theoretically clot.

anchor: And the first time Clancy clotted he was all worked up recounting his alien abduction he could have easily have been hypertensive.
response: I know I get worked up when I cut microParkp tracking implants out of my neck.

anchor: Sounds like a cheat to me.
response: Yeah, we get it. Okay, what's the differential for a sEven-year-old boy suffering multiple hypertensive crises?

anchor: It's clean, his heart isn't the pRoblem.
response: Why don't I have hi-def in my office? I'm a department head!

anchor: Valves are intact.
response: Tissue characterization is impossible when the pixels are the size of Legos.

anchor: Tissue characterization is impossible when the pixels are the size of Legos.
response: See, this is what I'm talking about. Foreman, you've got to steal this thing for me.

anchor: The clearer the image, the clearer it is that there are no masses, no clots, no tears. The pRoblem's got to be somewhere else.
response: We're gonna need a bigger boat.

anchor: Think he'll make us break into the IMAX before he admits it?
response: There.

anchor: There. Where?
response: Right there.

anchor: We don't have a laser pointer.
response: Well, why not?

anchor: So you found an arrhythmia.
response: That's not an arrhythmia, that's a no-rhythmia. Myocytes contract, these aren't moving at all. Go get me those myocytes I want to talk to them in my office.

anchor: How's the kid doing?
response: Heart nearly exploded.

anchor: What's going on with the leg?
response: First, tell me what's going on with the boobs.

anchor: If you're feeling pain
response: They're firmer.

anchor: It's called an underwire. I want to get a PET scan of your brain.
response: I think it's hormones.

anchor: As long as there's no increased activity in the thalamus
response: Looks to me like those puppies are going into the dairy business.

anchor: -- Then the pain can be good. It could be muscle regenerating. After you work out, you get sore. Pain doesn't mean the ketamine failed.
response: Guess I should be saying 'mazel tov.' Who gets to pass out the cigars?

anchor: I'm not pregnant. I need to get a PET scan of your brain.
response: Boy or girl? You got a name picked out?

anchor: I'm not pregnant!
response: My leg doesn't hurt.

anchor: You're in denial!
response: No, I'm not! Oh, you got me. If I thought my leg was deteriorating, don't you think I'd want to take steps to prEvent that?

anchor: Sighs. Okay. House's beeper beeps.
response: Gotta go. As he leaves, he fake stumbles. Cuddy helps him up He gives her a look with a ha.

anchor: Here's Clancy's DNA, and here's the DNA from the piece of that heart we just biopsied. They don't match.
response: That is impossible. Run it again.

anchor: The genes from Clancy's myocytes don't match the genes from the rest of his body. Alien DNA.
response: Anybody watch any X-Files that inspired an explanation?

anchor: There are ways DNA could become mutated. Extreme UV radiation.
response: That much sun, he'd be dying with a healthy bronze glow.

anchor: Nitrous acid or ethidium bromide exposure.
response: So first Daddy was a rapist, now he's a chemist.

anchor: Various species of fungus have been proven mutagenic.
response: Not unless the kid's been eating barrels of celery or living in Indonesia, or both.

anchor: Is your leg hurting?
response: Is that question helping?

anchor: Is that question helping? You're leaning.
response: You're sitting.

anchor: You're sitting. You're evading.
response: My head's hurting. Please, someone give me a plausible, terrestrial explanation for this kid's alien DNA.

anchor: What if we find the heart cells with the bad DNA and we tag them?
response: Can you phrase that in the form of a metaphor?

anchor: It's the same way we search for cancer. The bad DNA creates a unique protein on the surface of the affected cells. We create an antibody that recognizes only that protein and we flush it throughout his system, and the similar cells light up like light bulbs.
response: Okay, let's do that.

anchor: You want to go for a run?
response: What do you want?

anchor: I want you to run. He throws House a bottle of Vicodin.
response: When did you become an enabler?

anchor: I'm enabling you to exercise. Vicodin blocks the pain, you get through your rehab, muscle strength increases, and pain decreases.
response: I'd rather not become dependant on pain pills to get through my day. He throws them back.

anchor: You're just like any other Patient running away from knowledge that won't make you happy.
response: I'm as happy as a pig in poop.

anchor: You're scared the ketamine treatment's wearing off. That it was just a tortuous window of the good life.
response: What part of poop didn't you understand?

anchor: How can you be so sure it isn't just a sore muscle?
response: It's my leg. We've known each other a long time.

anchor: We didn't miss anything. Brain scan was completely clean.
response: Our tag must not have penetrated the blood-brain barrier. Don't use an IV this time get it right into the brain.

anchor: His scan was clean, twice! It's not there! House sits making them pause.
response: What if it is there but didn't show up on the scan?

anchor: Where are we going?
response: I am going to think.

anchor: I am going to think.
response: Send the kid home.

anchor: What do you mean?
response: Make sure his blood pressure's stabilized and send him home.

anchor: Like nothing Ever happened?
response: We cured his bleeding disorder, removed all the damaged cells we could find.

anchor: We don't know that we fixed anything, it's only been a day. Maybe these symptoms come and go like the blood disorder.
response: It's more pRobable that his remaining symptoms are just a nightmare.

anchor: He had a convulsion.
response: May be epilepsy, may be psychological, may be nothing.

anchor: House! You're just giving up on this kid?
response: You've got to know when to stop.

anchor: You don't stop, you nEver stop, you just keep on going until you come up with something so insane that it's usually right.
response: Except on my last case.

anchor: Don't be pathetic. Just forget the last case. This kid obviously has something wrong with him.
response: When did you dEvelop such strong opinions about my Patients? Last week you were convinced that my Patient wasn't sick, now you're convinced this one is.

anchor: This one is a young boy. His parents are desperate. Just get together with your team, spend a few extra hours
response: Well, I guess we could amputate his left leg. That's where we found most of it. Maybe we could just remove his affected eye completely.

anchor: If you have reason to beliEve that that might help
response: I'm not going to start lopping off body parts, but it's interesting that you'd give me the green light.

anchor: I just want you to do something.

anchor: Fiction is a waste of time unless you can laugh at it.
response: I love to laugh. Moving on. Moves the laptop again showing a glimpse of the half bottle of bourbon on the coffee table.

anchor: Back up. House stops. How bad is the insomnia? Let me quantify that. Do you drink two or three scotches before passing out in front of the TV?
response: You are so far off. It's bourbon. Gives her a better look at the bottle. Then continues showing the apartment.

anchor: No photos anywhere. Family and friends aren't important?
response: Well, you're sick. You have 20 people down the hall and you've had exactly one visitor.

anchor: I don't want to panic anyone.
response: You don't like people. You hide on that ice cube so!

anchor: Stop projecting. You're anti-social, so you assume I'm anti-social.

response: Great. You've got me all figured out. You going to try and fix me now?

anchor: We're going to be here all night.
response: How long does it take you to get naked?

response: I saw socks. That's not naked.

anchor: Have I mentioned it's freezing here? When they discover lymph nodes in feet, I will take off my socks.
response: Use your right hand to palpate the nodes. Any node you can feel is one we can biopsy. Let's start with your breasts, move down to the ass, then...

anchor: I was thinking... go from the neck and work my way down.
response: Well, you could. But I'd nEver forgive myself if we found something before we got to your breasts.

anchor: I'm starting with the anterior cervical nodes. Starts to feel her neck, House sits up and puts down the drink.
response: Turn your head. LoCate the SCM muscle.

response: Just thought it might help you relax. Anything in the axillary nodes?

anchor: All clear. Both sides.
response: Slide your hand to your sternum, pRobe for nodes. Moving slowly downward. Cate does as told.

anchor: Down to what, House?
response: Sorry, can't hear you on account of your heavy breathing.

anchor: I'm supposed to be on oxygen, you tool.
response: Turns off the music. Hold it. Cate stops. Your fingers didn't go quite as deep. Feel that node again.

anchor: Feel that node again. It!it's swollen.
response: Looks like you're doing a biopsy.

anchor: Okay, take a deep breath... and insert the needle into the node.
response: Come on, Cate. Let's get this over with.

anchor: Mutes the microphone.You used her name.
response: Just trying to move things along, Bob. Wilson un-mutes.

anchor: You need to pull back on the syringe. Cate tries to pull but nothing happens. You need to pull harder. Cate does so and screams in pain as the syringe fills with some sort of yellow liquid.
response: You okay?

response: It's a valid medical question.

anchor: I have nEver heard you ask a Patient that question. You've nEver asked me that question, and you've seen me fall down a flight of stairs drunk. You've slept with her.

anchor: No, you are definitely following me.
response: Where are you going?

anchor: Out to lunch.

response: Well done.

response: Just take the prednisone!

response: Take off her socks. Sean moves to her feet.

response: This one you will feel.

response: He drilled a hole in your skull after drinking your pee. I think he's up for this.

anchor: Grab the tip of her toe with your right hand. Hold the break with the other. Sean does as he's told. On the count of three, pull hard. One... two... three. Sean pulls, we hear a loud crack and Cate screams.

anchor: Bette Davis - another strong, assertive Woman.

response: Hasidic women marry young so they can start pushing out little Hasidilings.

anchor: humoring him I can't wait. It's gonna be awesome.

response: drops the book on the nearby table Your goal is pure feral vengeance.

anchor: So... which is it, House? Am I in this for you? Or am I in this for him?
response: Give him back his sweatshirt. 'Pit stains don't become you.

response: Except for the one you missed.

anchor: There's no change in her condition.
response: I'm not talking about a new symptom. I'm talking about one that presented six months ago.

anchor: No, no, if she walked away from Everything to go base jumping or live with apes, we wouldn't be having this discussion.

anchor: Then we will settle for second-best, someone who doesn't think my wife is sick just because she's religious.

anchor: But you follow the ones you don't understand because the ones you do understand make sense, and you beliEve that the guy who created them knows what he's doing. Of course.
